intro: Micropholis gardneriana, commonly known as the Mexican mahogany, is a small evergreen tree native to southern Mexico and Central America. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its smooth, dark-brown bark and elliptical leaves that are glossy on top and pale underneath. The plant produces small, white, fragrant flowers that bloom in clusters, followed by red, fleshy berries containing seeds. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates and is often found in moist, well-drained soils in forested areas. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
